description.narrative: Soluciones locales, integrales y eficientes que contribuyan al aprendizaje colectivo, apoyen la implementación de políticas públicas e impulsen el desarrollo sostenible del país.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

1. Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1. 5 new data sources per year 1.1.1. Qualitative fieldwork (focus groups and KIIs) for Collective Intelligence in SDE 1.1.2. SEIA (RedACTUA) survey on COVID socioeconomic impact on vulnerable populations 1.1.3. MSME micro-survey with 1.1.4. Social media listening study (Citibeats, mapping perceptions for dissemination of misinformation/fake news) 1.1.5. Regional MSME Challenge Prize Acceleration 2030 – A regional mapping of initiatives and opportunities for the reactivation of MSME in the DR and the LAC region. 1.1.6. Nacional Challenge Prize with private sector and UN agencies (UNESCO, WHO) called Espacios de Futuro (Future Spaces in English), an initiative to call for proposals of urban interventions for a safe and more inclusive return in the use of public and private spaces in cities.
1.2. 6 different type of data sources per year 1.2.1. Qualitative/ethnographic 1.2.2. Socioeconomic digital surveys 1.2.3. Social Media: Twitter perceptions capturing data. 1.2.4. Citizen data (citizen-generated data e.g., perception surveys / feedback mechanisms, etc.) 1.2.5. Official data: Government household surveys 1.2.6. Official data: SIUBEN poverty census data 1.2.7. Trends data to seek information lag. 1.2.8. Geospatial data: of lol communities related with the waste management action cycle.
1.3. 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.3.1. Through the Aceleración 2030 SMEs Challenge the AccLab was able to map about 60+ solutions. It is worth mentioning some of the most relevant for the CO: a)eHospital: an AI-powered virtual health care project. This solution was selected by UNDP Digital XScale initiative for additional funding and piloting. b) Several online marketplace solutions for SMEs to go digital. c) Digital payment processing platforms for SMEs. d) Biosafety artifacts for SMEs’ interactions with customers
1.4. 5 innovation methods per Action Plan. 1.4.1. Gamification: We build a virtual trivia game to learn from the skills, attitudes and practices of students about solid waste management. 1.4.2. Design Thinking: Inspiration methods were used to understand the problem and the actors 1.4.3. Human Centered Design: jointly with Design Thinking, or in tandem with, we worked with different actors mapping the problems and citizen perspectives around the management of solid waste 1.4.4. Sensemaking: We work with Chora Foundation, in the regional pilot of Sensemaking portfolio design (problem space) 1.4.5. Collective Intelligence: In conjunction with Nesta, we use the methodology to understand and define the recurrence management system specifically in the locality, Los Tres Brazos de Santo Domingo Este. 1.4.6. Solutions mapping through field visits in two (2) neighborhoods of the country’s capital (Los Tres Brazos and Domingo Savio).
2. Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1. At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 1) Aceleración 2030 Mipymes: Reto regional recolecta 56 experiencias de Latinoamérica y el Caribe de renovación y recuperación de negocios frente a la COVID-19 https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/presscenter/articles/2020/Aceleracion-2030-Publicacion.html 2) Entidades abren reto “Espacios de Futuro” para soluciones de rediseño urbano ante la COVID-19 https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/presscenter/articles/2020/entidades-abren-reto-espacios-de-futuro-para-soluciones-de-redis.html 3) PNUD-Laboratorio de Aceleración, UNESCO y Citibeats impulsan una alianza para combatir la infodemia por COVID-19 en la República Dominicana https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/presscenter/articles/2020/Combatir-desinformacion-en-Republica-Dominicana.html 4) Alianzas e innovación: aspectos claves para acelerar la recuperación de las mipymes en América Latina y El Caribe https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/blog/alianzas-e-innovacion--aspectos-claves-para-acelerar-la-recupera.html 5) “Ponte en Marcha”: una apuesta por la recuperación rápida y sostenible de las mipymes dominicanas https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/blog/_ponte-en-marcha--una-apuesta-por-la-recuperacion-rapida-y-soste.html 6) Escuchando las voces y creando alianzas para la recuperación de las mipymes https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/blog/escuchando-las-voces-y-creando-alianzas-para-la-recuperacion-de-.html 7) Creatividad e Innovación: un llamado a las personas a explorar estas cualidades https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/blog/creatividad-y-la-innovacion--un-llamado-a-las-personas-a-explora.html 8) Teletrabajo y equipos resilientes https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/blog/teletrabajo-y-equipos-resilientes.html
2.2. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.2.1. The Acceleracion 2030 SMEs challenge was launched in close collaboration with the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, the Central American Integration System (Spanish: Sistema de la Integración Centroamericana, or SICA, and other 29 institutional partners from 9 LAC countries. 2.2.2. The “Survey of economic effects on MSMEs due to the COVID-19 crisis”, carried out by the Ministry of Industry, Commerce and MSMEs (MICM), UNDP, Princeton University and the Office of the Vice President / Social Policy Coordination Agency. 2.2.3. The lab’s work on solid waste management has been in close collaboration with UK’s Nesta, through their Collective Intelligence framework. Additionally, the project has been well received by one of the country’s largest municipalities. 2.2.4. The lab’s work on social media listening on fake news (misinformation) during the pandemic was implemented in collaboration with UNESCO and Citibeats. 2.2.5. An analysis of the tourism industry through a Systems Thinking/Problem Space methodology was conducted during an 8-week workshop with the Chora Foundation (UK) and the UNDP’s office of innovation and partnerships (HQ).
2.3. At least one government entity or partner has adopted an accelerator lab method. • The Ministry of Industry, Commerce and MSMEs, addressed the challenge of working Aceleración 2030 in partnership with UNDP/AccLab, using participatory methodologies for design and implementation: UK’s Nesta challenge prize, agile principles, concept tests, iteration, among others. • Jointly with the private sector unit of UNDP, we developed an instrument to measure the scale of innovation in a private loan association.
2.4. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. The “Survey of economic effects on MSMEs due to the COVID-19 crisis”, carried out by the Ministry of Industry, Commerce and MSMEs (MICM), the UNDP, Princeton University and the Office of the Vice President/Social Policy Coordination Agency. The survey results have been useful for different public interventions, such as financial incentives and assistance to MSMEs and informal vendors and start different initiatives as: a) the COs MSMEs support strategy, B) the design of the Future Spaces application areas, and C) support for the digitization of MSMEs through grants with the private sector. All actions to combat the impact of COVID-19.
3. Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1. The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. (Teams, WhatsApp.) 1) Working together for the validation or design of initiatives, for example, the COs of Argentina, Mexico and Bolivia disseminated in their countries the call for the regional Acceleration 2030 SMEs challenge. 2) Presenting to the Uruguay AccLab the method of data collection Citibeats. 3) The global network’s weekly call (about 50+ a year) has given us an opportunity to interact and share with other labs in the network about specific themes of mutual interest (e.g., solid waste management; gamification).
3.2. 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. (Teams, WhatsApp.)
1) After an 8-week long virtual training workshop on Collective Intelligence and waste management, we shared our results with about other 8 AccLab teams from different regions. The information was shared via email, including PowerPoint presentations and through conversations about our approach to understanding the problem.
2) We consulted with several offices of the meeting (Mexico, Argentina, Bolivia) to carry out a regional mapping of the opportunities for economic reactivation in MSMEs. In the end, we received proposals from 8 countries of the meeting, which we reached thanks to the 29 alliances with entities in LAC. The information was shared via email, including PowerPoint presentations and virtual meetings with each country and partners.
3.3. The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. Google Analytics, Twitter, Medium and LinkedIn engagement metrics. • Our work has been featured more than three times on the UNDP social media platforms. • Some of our publications (blog pieces) were then featured in print by local newspapers. • The Innovation and Intellectual Property Week has been published on social media pages. https://www.instagram.com/p/B_OCwgUDnqD/ • https://www.instagram.com/p/CE9X7VAj8bH/ República Dominicana UNLEASH Hack! • UNESCO Y PNUD, dia internacional de la innovación y la creatividad. https://es.unesco.org/news/creatividad-e-innovacion-llamado-personas-explorar-estas-cualidades • Entidades abren reto “Espacios de Futuro” para soluciones de rediseño urbano ante la COVID-19 https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/presscenter/articles/2020/entidades-abren-reto-espacios-de-futuro-para-soluciones-de-redis.html
3.4. Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. (Twitter, blog posts from identified actors of the Development ecosystem.) 1. The call for Spaces for the Future initiative for urban redesign solutions has started. (More than 3 social media post and newspaper mentioned the initiative). https://www.instagram.com/ecoredrd/ 2. http://www.ecored.org.do/ya-inicio-la-convocatoria-de-espacios-de-futuro-iniciativa-para-soluciones-de-rediseno-urbano-ante-la-covid-19/ 3. https://invertix.com.do/entidades-abren-reto-espacios-de-futuro-para-soluciones-de-rediseno-urbano-ante-la-covid-19/ 4. Share with the region, stories, and solutions ready or in an advanced phase to be implemented in MSME’s related to the topics: occupational health and safety; agile payment methods; and logistics and distribution chains. https://www.instagram.com/p/CCoWy9YjAku/?igshid=1vmj6j49uz6vb

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1. 2 new sources of data per year: A) Qualitative/ethnographic data of rural communities of women producers with banana stem fiber B) SIUBEN Household poverty census C) National Statistics Office demographic data
1.2. 3 different type of data sources per year: A) Qualitative/ethnographic data B) Government household data C) Specialized literature
1.3. 20 new potential solutions per lab per year: Initial proposals for smart waste management were drafted, including: • Smart containers • GPS garbage collection tracking • Cash incentives for plastic reduction at small shops in neighborhoods • Vending machines for plastic-for-cash incentives
1.4. 2 innovation methods per Action Plan: • Sensemaking: It was applied in the initial phase of the AccLab, to understand the issues on which we would be working. • Design thinking: Applied to the collaborations provided to UNDP partners. • Solutions mapping: applied during initial phase of the AccLab, looked for unknow and grassroots solutions in three communities.
2. Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1. 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year: PNUD apuesta por la innovación social para alcanzar los ODS https://www.diariolibre.com/actualidad/tecnologia/pnud-apuesta-por-la-innovacion-social-para-alcanzar-los-ods-DM14903819 Laboratorio de Aceleración: un nuevo enfoque para lograr el desarrollo sostenible https://www.do.undp.org/content/dominican_republic/es/home/blog/2019/laboratorio-de-aceleracion--un-nuevo-enfoque-para-lograr-el-desa.html
2.2. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 1) Our first learning challenge was focused on women socioeconomic empowerment in Valverde province, with close collaboration with UNDP’s Gender Unit, Ministry of Industry, Commerce and MSMEs and local grassroots organizations. 2) The design of the solid waste management challenge began by exploring the issue with municipalities in the Greater Santo Domingo area, private sector and academic stakeholders.
2.3. At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. We collaborated with the Ministry of Economy, Planning and Development to implement the ‘Territorial Cohesion Fund’. Our sensemaking and stakeholder engagement methods were useful for the first phase of the project.
2.4. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. The lab provided technical support to the Ministry of the Presidency’s office of special projects, in the draft of presidential order no. 175-20 on an innovation ecosystem strategy creation.
3. Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1. The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year. • Training bootcamp (Ecuador) • Active participation during initial weeks of learning on Teams and WhatsApp • Started participating in the network’s weekly call. (Drop-in Sessions)
3.2. 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. We created a local (DR) innovation ecosystem stakeholder mapping for which we were asked to share the methodology with the network’s global team.
3.3. The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account.
Launch activity of the UNDP’s Accelerator’s lab: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EbCiVXkNYWs&t=6s
UNDP’s Senior Economist words on the launch of the Accelerators’ lab https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DkT2-_KrHz8
Launch Activity of the UNDP’s Accelerator’s Lab on Twitter: https://twitter.com/PNUDRD/status/1210550426468278272
3.4. Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. UNDP DR launches the Accelerator labs, to reach the SDGs. https://hoy.com.do/el-pnud-lanza-laboratorio-de-aceleracion-para-alcanzar-ods/
UNDP DR launches the Accelerator labs, to reach the SDGs with potential growth. Social Media post for our partner ECORED https://www.instagram.com/p/B39vAcBnPOq/?igshid=1br93fljzafpj
